pageData.text: Soil microbes perform many fundamental functions, such as nutrient cycling and promoting plant growth. However, observing these processes can be very difficult. The Winogradsky column is a useful tool for observing soil microbial community function. A Winogradsky column is a simple container containing soil, water, and any desired experimental additions, such as metals and organic matter. Over time, passive diffusion and microbial interactions within the column will provide unique but predictable formations. In this investigation, you will set up four columns and observe the visual differences between the microbial communities throughout oxygen and nutrient gradients.

pageData.text:
“Bog” is a common name for wetlands ecosystems in some parts of the world, especially those where peat can be extracted. The specific soil conditions of these peat bogs have allowed them to act as natural refrigerators for thousands of years, leading to the preservation of some interesting artifacts. In Ireland, there have been discoveries of
2,000-5,000-year-old butter, called “bog butter”, preserved in these peat bogs1. According to its discoverers, bog butter can still smell - and even taste - like fresh butter!

The reason this butter is so well preserved has to do with the microbial conditions of the soil. Peat bogs are highly anoxic with poor aeration, limiting the types of microorganisms that can survive and break down organic matter. These bogs are also highly acidic as a result of carbon dioxide absorption, anerobic respiration by soil microorganisms, and the ion exchange of sphagnum moss, which is the predominant species in peat bog locales. These chemical properties, combined with cool temperatures underneath the peat, allowed early humans to use bogs as natural refrigerators to keep their butter from spoiling until the next season – and beyond.

1Dailey, J. (2016, June 13). A Brief History of Bog Butter. Smithsonian Magazine.
https://www.smithsonianmag.com/smart-news/a-brief-history-of-bog-butter-180959384/

pageData.desc: A peat bog.
pageData.altText: A peat bog.

pageData.text: It is estimated that there are more microbes in a teaspoon of soil than there are people on Earth. Soil microorganisms include bacteria (actino-mycete bacteria are often what gives soil the “dirt” smell), archaea, fungi, algae, nematodes, protozoa, viruses, and <button class='glossary-text'>bacteriophages</button> (viruses that only infect bacteria). Collectively, they all play an important role in soil structure and fertility and metabolize a wide range of chemicals that are fundamental to nutrient cycles.

pageData.subTitle: Respiration Pathways and Factors Affecting Them
pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Soil organic matter (SOM)</button> is all the organic substances in the soil, both living and dead. Active SOM contains easily digested sugars and proteins, which microbes need to create new cells. In the presence of oxygen (O<sub>2</sub>), <button class='glossary-text'>aerobic respiration</button> occurs. <button class='glossary-text'>Soil aeration</button> refers to the supply of O<sub>2</sub> and thus the ability to support aerobic microorganisms.

Soil aeration is the exchange of gases-such as nitrogen (N2), O2, and carbon dioxide (CO2)- between the soil pores and the atmosphere (see Figure 1). For example, the ratio between O2 and CO2 can be used to determine how well the soil is aerated. A higher percentage of O2 means that the soil is well-aerated and is capable of supporting biological activity. The (AFP) is the percentage of the volume of the soil that is composed of air (i.e., a gas mixture) at any given time. Higher AFP means higher soil aeration. As water drains from soil, the fewer soil pores are filled with water, the more pores are filled with air, and the higher the air-filled porosity and aeration. The soil refers to how oxidized or reduced (anaerobic) the soil is as well as the electron availability in the soil. The higher the Eh, the more O2 and other oxidizing agents are available, and the more aerated the soil is. In (see ), electrons are transferred from the reducing agent to the oxidizing agent. Oxidation refers to the loss of electrons; reduction is the gain of electrons. In a redox reaction, the reducing agent is oxidized while the oxidizing agent is reduced.

pageData.desc:
Figure 1: Diagram of solid particles, air-filled pore space, and a plant root, with arrows showing CO2 flows up and O2 flows down. In the atmosphere, the O2 flows up and the CO2 flows down.
Porous soil allows for the movement of water and gases and promotes plant growth. Soil that is compacted is not porous and plants do not grow as well.
pageData.altText:
Figure 1: Diagram of solid particles, air-filled pore space, and a plant root, with arrows showing CO2 flows up and O2 flows down. In the atmosphere, the O2 flows up and the CO2 flows down.

pageData.desc:
Figure 2: Diagram of the chemicals of rusting, showing O2 (water) plus Fe (a screw) plus H2O (rain) right arrow Fe2O2H2O (a rusty screw).
Rusting is the formation of iron oxide. It is formed by the redox reaction of oxygen, water, and iron and its alloys.
pageData.altText:
Figure 2: Diagram of the chemicals of rusting, showing O2 (water) plus Fe (a screw) plus H2O (rain) right arrow Fe2O2H2O (a rusty screw).
Rusting is the formation of iron oxide. It is formed by the redox reaction of oxygen, water, and iron and its alloys.

pageData.text: In the soil, plant roots and aerobic microbes perform . Aerobic respiration requires O2. A common soil redox reaction involves the oxidation of carbohydrates and the simultaneous reduction of O2. In the process of respiration, electrons are transferred from electron-rich molecules and transferred to electron-poor molecules. The respiring organism uses energy from this process to drive biochemical reactions (see Figure 3). In the absence of O2, aerobic respiration stops and alternative electron acceptors are used. This process is called . In the presence of low or no oxygen, the soil microbial community and pH are changed.

pageData.desc:
Figure 3: Two formulas: sugar plus oxygen right arrow CO2 plus H2O plus energy; then C6H12O6 plus 6 O2 right arrow 6 CO2 plus 6 H2O plus ATP
Glucose is oxidized to produce carbon dioxide, and oxygen is reduced to produce water.
pageData.altText:
Figure 3: Two formulas: sugar plus oxygen right arrow CO2 plus H2O plus energy; then C6H12O6 plus 6 O2 right arrow 6 CO2 plus 6 H2O plus ATP
Glucose is oxidized to produce carbon dioxide, and oxygen is reduced to produce water.

pageData.question: What is required for aerobic respiration?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: In the soil, plant roots and aerobic microbes perform aerobic respiration. Aerobic respiration requires O<sub>2</sub>.

pageData.question: In aerobic respiration, what is glucose oxidized to?

feedbackData.title: Feedback

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Aerobic respiration is respiration that occurs in the presence of oxygen gas (O<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>). In the process of aerobic respiration, glucose is oxidized to carbon dioxide (CO<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>).

hintData.body: Aerobic respiration is respiration that occurs in the presence of oxygen gas (O<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>). In the process of aerobic respiration, glucose is oxidized to carbon dioxide (CO<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>).

pageData.text: A “typical” soil consists of approximately one-half particles and one-half pores. Under optimum conditions for biological activity, roughly one-half of the soil pore volume is filled with air and one-half with water. In very dry soils, only small micropores are filled with water. Rarely are soils so dry that all pores are air-filled. In very wet soils, most pores are filled with water. However, there are usually some pores that contain trapped air, even in very wet soils.

In both the atmosphere and in soil air, N<sub>2</sub>, O<sub>2</sub>, and CO<sub>2</sub> are the major constituents. All plants and animals (including humans) must have oxygen. The same is true for many, but not all, microorganisms. Soil air differs from atmospheric air due to the biological activity of soil organisms. Relative to the atmosphere, soil air is usually depleted of O<sub>2</sub> and enriched with CO<sub>2</sub>. Soil air is also usually much more humid than atmospheric air. Like the atmosphere above, soil air is dominated by di-nitrogen gas (N<sub>2</sub>). Oxygen is usually the second most prevalent gas, although the soil atmosphere generally contains less than half as much O<sub>2</sub> as the Earth’s atmosphere. The soil air is enriched in CO<sub>2</sub> compared to the atmosphere above due to <button class='glossary-text'>aerobic respiration</button>, and may be enriched in other gases, such as nitrous oxide (N<sub>2</sub>O) and methane (CH<sub>2</sub>), particularly under anaerobic conditions.

Gases move in soils via two processes: mass flow and diffusion. Mass flow refers to the bulk flow of gases in response to pressure differences. These can occur due to water flow that can trap air and compress air in soil pores or due to weather changes in atmospheric pressure. The barometric pressure changes are due to the presence of high- or low-pressure weather systems that can push air into the soil or allow air to flow out of the soil. Diffusion refers to the flow of gases or solutes from areas of high concentration to areas of low concentration. Diffusion occurs when the air in one part of the soil is enriched or depleted of individual constituents relative to other parts of the soil. Such concentration gradients result from biological activity, such as respiration. Generally, due to microbial respiration enriching soil in CO<sub>2</sub> and depleting it of O<sub>2</sub>, O<sub>2</sub> diffuses into the soil and CO<sub>2</sub> diffuses out (see <button class='resource-text'>Figure 1</button>)</button>.

Along with passive air movement, bacteria, fungi, and other microorganisms in the soil respire. These microbes are virtually everywhere in soil, but they are most abundant near a source of food, such as a carbon-rich piece of plant detritus or other <button class='glossary-text'>SOM</button>. The microbes feeding on such a carbon source grow rapidly, consuming lots of O<sub>2</sub> and producing copious CO<sub>2</sub>. Therefore, areas of soil closest to carbon sources are less aerated than areas farther from carbon sources.

pageData.subTitle: Wetlands and Saturated Soils
pageData.text: Wetland soils are poorly aerated and thus likely anaerobic, but there are poorly aerated soils in other situations also. Many soils can become

header.text: Differences in Inorganic Composition of Aerobic and Anaerobic Soils

pageData.text:
*CO2 can remain present in somewhat anaerobic soils (i.e., under sub-oxic to sulfidic conditions),
but after microbes use up available SO242, they switch to reducing CO2 down to CH2.
**Although O2 gas is absent from anaerobic soils, O is still found in other compounds, such as H2O, and SO42-.

anaerobic for short periods of time following rains or irrigation events. This is particularly true of soil with high clay contents, soils with low porosity, or deep soil profiles close to groundwater.

Anaerobic soils differ from aerobic soils in several ways. Plant roots require O2. Plants that live in wetlands have mechanisms that carry O2 down from above the water to the roots through specialized structures. In anaerobic soils, microorganisms that require O2 for respiration will die or go dormant, and anaerobic organisms that can use alternative electron acceptors will take over. Also, there are that can use either O2 or alternative electron acceptors. By-products of may accumulate, and reduced metals (mainly iron and manganese) will solubilize and may reach toxic levels. Table 1 highlights some of the other differences in inorganic aerobic and anaerobic soils.

pageData.question: In aerobic soil, what is the predominant source of iron?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: In aerobic soil, the predominant source of iron is ferric iron (Fe<sup>3</sup><sup>+</sup>).

pageData.question: In anaerobic soil, what is the predominant source of sulfur?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: In anaerobic soil, the predominant source of sulfur is sulfide (S<sup>2</sup><sup>-</sup>).

header.text: Differences in Inorganic Composition of Aerobic and Anaerobic Soils
Differences in Inorganic Composition of Aerobic and Anaerobic Soils

pageData.text: Redox gradients are commonly found in soils and aquatic environments as functions of space and time and are caused by varying chemical properties, including the availability of oxygen, <button class='glossary-text'>soil aeration</button>, chemicals present, and microbial processes. Due to the slow diffusion of O<sub>2</sub> gas through water, only microbes in the topmost layer of a flooded or wetland soil can access sufficient O<sub>2</sub> for <button class='glossary-text'>aerobic respiration</button>. After flooding, microbes start at the top of the <button class='glossary-text'>redox ladder</button> (see Figure 4), using O<sub>2</sub> as an oxidizing agent first, then Mn<sup>4</sup><sup>+</sup>, Fe<sup>3</sup><sup>+</sup>, and SO<sub>4</sub><sup>2</sup><sup>-</sup>.

pageData.desc:
Figure 4: Color-coded “staircase,” from top to bottom: aerobes, denitrifiers, manganese reducers, iron reducers, sulfate reducers, and methanogens
The redox ladder, like a staircase, with the most energetically favorable reaction at the top (aerobic) and least at the bottom (anerobic).
pageData.altText:
Figure 4: Color-coded “staircase,” from top to bottom: aerobes, denitrifiers, manganese reducers, iron reducers, sulfate reducers, and methanogens
The redox ladder, like a staircase, with the most energetically favorable reaction at the top (aerobic) and least at the bottom (anerobic).

pageData.text: Poor <button class='glossary-text'>soil aeration</button> can have some negative impacts on air and water. When E<sub>h</sub> is low, microbes use NO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup> as an electron acceptor instead of O<sub>2</sub>, producing N<sub>2</sub>O and N<sub>2</sub>. When E<sub>h</sub> is very low, microbes may also use CO<sub>2</sub> as an electron acceptor, which produces methane (CH<sub>4</sub>). Both N<sub>2</sub>O and CH<sub>4</sub> are powerful greenhouse gases. In soils that are naturally poorly aerated, these emissions constitute part of the natural carbon and nitrogen cycles, helping to maintain a steady concentration of atmospheric greenhouse gases (see <button class='resource-text'>Figure 5</button>). However, if the soil becomes saturated for prolonged periods due to human activity (example, constructing a rice paddy), then N<sub>2</sub>O and CH<sub>4</sub> concentrations increase and contribute to climate change. Leaching of toxic metals can become a problem when the soil has an especially high concentration of a toxic metal, such as arsenic. Arsenic, like many metals, is more soluble in its reduced form. Therefore, poorly aerated soils that are high in arsenic may leach arsenic and pollute the groundwater.

Soils that are anaerobic for significant portions of the time change character visibly. The continued reducing conditions lead to visible features that we use to identify these soils as <button class='glossary-text'>hydric</button>. Hydric soil is formed under conditions of saturation or flooding for long enough that develops anaerobic conditions in the upper area. <button class='glossary-text'>Mottling</button> is a blotchy pattern caused by alternate wetting and drying. The bright colors are caused by oxidized ferric iron (Fe<sup>3</sup><sup>+</sup>), and the dull colors by ferrous iron (Fe<sup>2</sup><sup>+</sup>) or the absence of Fe altogether. If soils remain saturated for long periods of time, all the iron and manganese become reduced, and the soil turns a dull gray or bluish color (gleying). Blue colors are from Fe<sup>2+</sup> minerals, whereas grey colors are typically from Al minerals left behind when the more soluble Fe<sup>2+</sup> leaches (dissolves and flows downward) out of the soil.

pageData.desc:
Figure 5: Nitrogen cycle, labeled with important processes as described in the caption
The nitrogen cycle is the biogeochemical cycle by which nitrogen is converted into multiple chemical forms as it circulates among atmospheric, terrestrial, and marine ecosystems. The conversion of nitrogen can be carried out through both biological and phys-ical processes. Important processes in the nitrogen cycle include fixation, ammonification, nitrification, and denitrification.
pageData.altText:
Figure 5: Nitrogen cycle, labeled with important processes as described in the caption
The nitrogen cycle is the biogeochemical cycle by which nitrogen is converted into multiple chemical forms as it circulates among atmospheric, terrestrial, and marine ecosystems. The conversion of nitrogen can be carried out through both biological and phys-ical processes. Important processes in the nitrogen cycle include fixation, ammonification, nitrification, and denitrification.

pageData.question: Which of the following is the most energetically favorable reaction?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The most energetically favorable reaction can be found at the top of the redox ladder.

Due to the slow diffusion of O<sub>2</sub> gas through water, only microbes in the topmost layer of a flooded or wetland soil can access sufficient O<sub>2</sub> for aerobic respiration. After flooding, microbes start at the top of the redox ladder (see Figure 4), using O<sub>2</sub> as an oxidizing agent first, then Mn<sup>4</sup><sup>+</sup>, Fe<sup>3</sup><sup>+</sup>, and SO<sub>4</sub> <sup>2-</sup>.

The redox ladder, like a staircase, with the most energetically favorable reaction at the top (aerobic) and least at the bottom (anerobic).

Due to the slow diffusion of O2 gas through water, only microbes in the topmost layer of a flooded or wetland soil can access sufficient O2 for aerobic respiration. After flooding, microbes start at the top of the redox ladder (see Figure 4), using O2 as an oxidizing agent first, then Mn<sup>4</sup><sup>+</sup>, Fe<sup>3</sup><sup>+</sup>, and SO<sub>4</sub> <sup>2-</sup>.

pageData.subTitle: Winogradsky Column
pageData.text: A Winogradsky column is used to study the redox potential of environments and the many possible gradients that can form. In this activity, you will construct four Winogradsky columns and add different variables to simulate and compare the redox potential of different wetlands. Several potential layers are shown in Figure 6, but you may only see a few of these layers.

The relationship between microbes and redox potential is incredibly important to the development of life on Earth. Microbes shape the environment and create ecological niches for other organisms. Without microbes, life as we know it on Earth would not exist. Evidence from ancient sedimentary rocks suggests that approximately three billion years ago, cyanobacteria gained the ability to photosynthesize, and began multiplying, which oxygenated the Earth. After oxygen started to accumulate, larger and more complex forms of life were able to evolve. In this activity, within your Winogradsky columns, little ecosystems will form in which the by-products from one group of microorganisms will support the growth of another.

pageData.desc:
Figure 6: Winogradsky column: air, cyanobacteria and algae in liquid, then bacteria—non-sulfar, purple, and green photosynthetic; and sulfate-reducing
A well-developed, idealized Winogradsky Column. The triangles represent how, with increasing depth, O2 concentrations decrease while hydrogen sulfide (H2S) concentrations increase due to decreasing aeration.
pageData.altText:
Figure 6: Winogradsky column: air, cyanobacteria and algae in liquid, then bacteria—non-sulfar, purple, and green photosynthetic; and sulfate-reducing
A well-developed, idealized Winogradsky Column. The triangles represent how, with increasing depth, O2 concentrations decrease while hydrogen sulfide (H2S) concentrations increase due to decreasing aeration.

A map describing the procedural workflow for this investigation. Before beginning, you will collect biologically active soil. In activity 1, label four Winogradsky column cups, then add water and soil to each. Then, set up the cups according to the label. If the label says +Carbon, add a carbon source to the cup. If the label says +MgSO4, add Epsom salt to the cup. If the label says +nail, add a nail to the cup. Then, cover the cup and poke holes in the cover. Next, place the cup in a warm location. This cup set up process is repeated for each of the four cups. Then, record your day 1 observations. Finally, record weekly observations for 6 weeks.

Wear your safety goggles, gloves, and lab apron for the duration of this investigation.

pageData.altText: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol
pageData.desc: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol

pageData.text: Read all the instructions for the laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely, and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE).

Never conduct fieldwork on your own, especially in remote areas; always take a responsible partner with you. Prepare and leave a field safety plan, complete with planned survey locations and expected return time, with a responsible party. Wear appropriate clothing (long pants and close-toed shoes are usually best), sunblock, and insect repellant if necessary. Be familiar with the potential hazards in your chosen survey areas. Please review the “Field Work” portion of the Laboratory Safety Manual or your school’s specific safety guidelines for more information. Make sure that you are healthy enough to participate in fieldwork. If in doubt, consult your medical practitioner.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing these activities. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing each activity. Clean the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: In anaerobic soil, what is the predominant source of carbon?
Which of the following statements about how gases move in soils is true?

options.text: Gases can move in bulk in response to changes in barometric pressure.
Gases move from areas of low concentration to areas of high concentration.
Low-pressure weather systems push air into the soil.
Concentration gradients of soil gases usually develop as a result of human activity.
Gases can move into soil, but they cannot be released from soil.

assestmentData.question: What is produced when glucose is oxidized?

2 parts particles : 2 parts microorganisms : 1 part pores

Read through the activities.
Obtain all materials.
Clean and sanitize the work space.

Using the 24-ounce deli container from the equipment kit, collect approximately 3 cups of biologically active soil from about 0–8 cm (0–3 inches) below the surface (enough to fill the cup almost to the top; see Figure 7). This sample is the “Collected Soil” sample. (The soil will be divided between four different treatments.)

pageData.desc: Figure 7: Twenty-four ounce deli container filled almost to the top with soil
pageData.altText: Figure 7: Twenty-four ounce deli container filled almost to the top with soil

pageData.text: Note: Biologically active soil can be found near plant roots or anywhere there is decomposing organic matter. Before using the sample, remove excess grasses, roots, and other plant materials and break up any large clumps. You may need to spread the soil out flat to find most of the plant residues. If your soil has a substantial amount (>10% or so) of coarse fragments like gravel or plant debris, you can sieve it with a colander or a sieve (see Figure 8).

pageData.desc: Figure 8: Unsifted soil in a colander and sifted soil in a bowl
pageData.altText: Figure 8: Unsifted soil in a colander and sifted soil in a bowl

pageData.text: Note: If you are unsure if a public location is appropriate to collect a sample from, contact your local Parks and Recreation, Fish and Wildlife, State Park, Bureau of Land Management, or National Forest Department.
In Activity 1, you will set up four Winogradsky columns with different nutrient availability using collected soil samples. You will then observe ecosystem formation within the column over six weeks.

Take the four 20-ounce plastic cups from the materials kit, and label them as follows (one for each sample):
  • Control
  • +Carbon
  • +Carbon + MgSO4
  • +Carbon + MgSO4 + Nail
Using the graduated cylinder, pour 75 mL of tap water in each of the cups.
Pour approximately ¼ of the Collected Soil into the “Control” cup (see Figure 9).

pageData.desc: Figure 9: The deli container with Collected Soil and the Control cup; about a fourth of the Collected Soil was added to water in the Control cup.
pageData.altText: Figure 9: The deli container with Collected Soil and the Control cup; about a fourth of the Collected Soil was added to water in the Control cup.

pageData.text: Add water to the “Control” cup to approximately 1 inch under the lip of the cup, and stir with a spoon.
Note: You do not need to wash the spoon between setting up the cups; you will add different nutrient sources in progression for each treatment.
Repeat Steps 3 for the “+Carbon” cup.

Add the carbon source (1 cup of torn newspaper, 4 ounces of sugar, or 1 cup of torn leaves), and stir Add water to the to cup approximately 1 inch under the lip of the cup and stir again with a spoon.
Repeat Steps 3 for the “+Carbon + MgSO<sub>4</sub>” cup.
Add the carbon source (1 cup of torn newspaper, 4 ounces of sugar, or 1 cup of torn leaves), and stir.

Use the digital scale and weigh boat. Measure 1.0 g of Epsom salt (MgSO<sub>4</sub>). Pour this into the “+Carbon + MgSO<sub>4</sub>” cup, and stir Add water to the to cup approximately 1 inch under the lip of the cup and stir again with a spoon.
Repeat Steps 3 and Steps 8 and 9 for the “+Carbon + MgSO<sub>4</sub> + Nail” cup. Add water to the to cup approximately 1 inch under the lip of the cup and stir again with a spoon.
Add the ungalvanized steel nail (a source of Fe) from the materials kit.
Cover each cup with parafilm, and secure it with a rubber band (see Figure 10).
Note: Parafilm is flexible and can be stretched to fit over the top of the cup.

pageData.desc: Figure 10: A 20-ounce cup with soil, filled with water, covered with parafilm that is secured with a rubber band
pageData.altText: Figure 10: A 20-ounce cup with soil, filled with water, covered with parafilm that is secured with a rubber band

pageData.text: Poke a few holes in the parafilm to allow gases to be released.
Place the cups in a warm location on top of a few paper towels (in case there is leaking) and out of direct sunlight where they will not be disturbed for the next six weeks.
Note: Your columns can also be put in a dark location.
Record your Day 1 observations and chosen location in Data Table 1.
Each week for the next six weeks, observe your columns. Note any changes you see in Data Table 1.

pageData.desc: camera symbol
pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Each week, take a photograph of your columns.<span class='bodyParaLineBreak'>
Note: You may keep your columns for longer if you choose.
Add 20 mL of household bleach to each culture. Allow this to stand for 4 hours.
pageData.desc: stopwatch symbol
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Pour off the liquid from each culture into a drain with the water running. Allow the faucet to run for 3 minutes to dilute the solution.
pageData.desc: stopwatch symbol
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Location

text: Did you observe changes in the control column?
What other set up could be a helpful control for this experiment? Explain your answer.
Winogradsky columns form oxygen concentration gradients. Predict the distribution of oxygen throughout the column.
Winogradsky columns form sulfide concentration gradients. Explain what occurred to the sulfur in your columns that contained MgSO<sub>4</sub>.
Desulfovibrio are a type of bacteria that can reduce sulfur. Where in the columns would you expect to find them? Why?
Where would you find photosynthetic organisms (i.e., cyanobacteria and algae)? Why?
How do Winogradsky columns illustrate the diversity of microorganisms found on Earth?

pageData.altText:
Figure 1: Diagram of solid particles, air-filled pore space, and a plant root, with arrows showing CO2 flows up and O2 flows down. In the atmosphere, the O2 flows up and the CO2 flows down.
Porous soil allows for the movement of water and gases and promotes plant growth. Soil that is compacted is not porous and plants do not grow as well.

Figure 2: Diagram of the chemicals of rusting, showing O2 (water) plus Fe (a screw) plus H2O (rain) right arrow Fe2O2H2O (a rusty screw).
Rusting is the formation of iron oxide. It is formed by the redox reaction of oxygen, water, and iron and its alloys.

Figure 3: Two formulas: sugar plus oxygen right arrow CO2 plus H2O plus energy; then C6H12O6 plus 6 O2 right arrow 6 CO2 plus 6 H2O plus ATP
Glucose is oxidized to produce carbon dioxide, and oxygen is reduced to produce water.

pageData.title: Table 1.
pageData.content: Table 1. Differences in inorganic composition of aerobic and anaerobic soils

header.text: Differences in Inorganic Composition of Aerobic and Anaerobic Soils

pageData.altText:
Figure 4: Color-coded “staircase,” from top to bottom: aerobes, denitrifiers, manganese reducers, iron reducers, sulfate reducers, and methanogens
The redox ladder, like a staircase, with the most energetically favorable reaction at the top (aerobic) and least at the bottom (anerobic).

Figure 5: Nitrogen cycle, labeled with important processes as described in the caption
The nitrogen cycle is the biogeochemical cycle by which nitrogen is converted into multiple chemical forms as it circulates among atmospheric, terrestrial, and marine ecosystems. The conversion of nitrogen can be carried out through both biological and phys-ical processes. Important processes in the nitrogen cycle include fixation, ammonification, nitrification, and denitrification.

Figure 6: Winogradsky column: air, cyanobacteria and algae in liquid, then bacteria—non-sulfar, purple, and green photosynthetic; and sulfate-reducing
A well-developed, idealized Winogradsky Column. The triangles represent how, with increasing depth, O2 concentrations decrease while hydrogen sulfide (H2S) concentrations increase due to decreasing aeration.

A map describing the procedural workflow for this investigation. Before beginning, you will collect biologically active soil. In activity 1, label four Winogradsky column cups, then add water and soil to each. Then, set up the cups according to the label. If the label says +Carbon, add a carbon source to the cup. If the label says +MgSO4, add Epsom salt to the cup. If the label says +nail, add a nail to the cup. Then, cover the cup and poke holes in the cover. Next, place the cup in a warm location. This cup set up process is repeated for each of the four cups. Then, record your day 1 observations. Finally, record weekly observations for 6 weeks.
Figure 7: Twenty-four ounce deli container filled almost to the top with soil

data.title: Aerobic respiration
data.content: The process of cellular respiration that takes place in the presence of oxygen gas to produce energy from food

data.title: Air-filled porosity (AFP)
data.content: The percentage of the volume of the soil that is composed of air at any given time; higher AFP means higher soil aeration

data.title: Anaerobic respiration
data.content: The process of respiration through which cells can break down sugars to generate energy in the absence of oxygen

data.title: Bacteriophage
data.content: A virus that only infects bacteria

data.title: Facultative anaerobe
data.content: A microorganism that can produce energy via aerobic respiration but then shift to anaerobic based on the quantity of oxygen and fermentable content present in the environment

data.title: Hydric
data.content: Describes soil that is formed under conditions of saturation or flooding and which develops anaerobic conditions in the upper area

data.title: Mottling
data.content: A blotchy pattern caused by alternative wetting and drying

data.title: Oxidation-reduction (redox) reaction
data.content: A reaction where electrons are transferred from the reducing agent to the oxidizing agent

data.title: Redox ladder
data.content: A visual representation of the order in which redox reactions occur based on the free energy gained from redox pairs

data.title: Redox potential (E<sub>h</sub>)
data.content: How oxidized or reduced (anaerobic) the soil is, as well as the electron availability in the soil

data.title: Soil aeration
data.content: The measure of the supply of oxygen gas in the soil

data.title: Soil organic matter (SOM)
data.content: All the organic substances in the soil, both living and dead
